William Shakespeare, one of the most influential writers in English literature, was born in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1564. He wrote 39 plays, 154 sonnets, and two long narrative poems. His works have been translated into every major living language and are performed more often than those of any other playwright. Despite his fame, much about his life remains a mystery, including the so-called "lost years" between 1585 and 1592 when there are no records of his activities.
What aspect of Shakespeare's life is referred to as the "lost years"?
A. His childhood in Stratford-upon-Avon
B. The period during which he wrote his sonnets
C. The time before he started writing plays
D. The years immediately following his death
E. The period between 1585 and 1592 with no records of his activities

The aspect of Shakespeare's life referred to as the "lost years" is E. The period between 1585 and 1592 with no records of his activities.

To elaborate, William Shakespeare was born in 1564 in Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He married Anne Hathaway in 1582, and they had three children. By 1592, Shakespeare was already established in London as an actor and playwright. However, there is a significant gap in the historical records of his life between 1585 and 1592, a period often referred to as the "lost years." During these seven years, there is very little documented evidence of what Shakespeare was doing or where he was living.

Scholars and historians have tried to piece together this missing period of Shakespeare's life, proposing various theories and possibilities. Some suggest that he worked as a teacher, while others believe he may have traveled extensively or even worked in a legal capacity. There are also speculations that he might have been involved in the theater industry in some capacity, perhaps as an actor or playwright, but without concrete evidence.

One popular theory is that Shakespeare spent time working in the households of wealthy families, possibly as a tutor or assistant, which would have exposed him to literature, politics, and high society, all of which could have influenced his later works. Another theory proposes that he worked as a lawyer's clerk or studied law, which could explain the detailed legal knowledge exhibited in some of his plays.

Moreover, there are tales of Shakespeare poaching deer from the estate of Thomas Lucy, a local justice of the peace, and having to flee Stratford as a result. This story, though intriguing, lacks substantial evidence and is considered more legend than fact.

In recent years, some researchers have suggested that Shakespeare might have spent time in Italy during the lost years, given the frequent settings of his plays in Italian cities like Venice and Verona. However, there is no direct evidence to support this theory.

The lack of information about this period in Shakespeare's life has led to much speculation and has contributed to the enduring mystery surrounding the life of England's greatest playwright. It also fuels the ongoing debates about the authorship of his works, with some suggesting that someone else wrote the plays and poems attributed to Shakespeare.

In conclusion, the "lost years" of Shakespeare refer to the period between 1585 and 1592 when there are scant records of his activities, leaving scholars and enthusiasts to speculate about what he was doing during that time. This period remains one of the most intriguing puzzles in the study of Shakespeare's life and work.
